Posts.Content: May 26, 2009 02:50PM Lisa810 wrote: hmmm, should i be calling my "peach fuzz" "duck hair" instead? i've never heard of that one! i just love how it feels. sooooo soft! i can't bear the thought of my eyelashes coming in only to fall out again. *sniffle* i've gotten quite good at filling in my brows, even without the stencils. Anastasia's Brow Ex-press kit totally rocks! i can't wait to have my new hair trimmed and styled next month when i go to my wig angel (to have my wig trimmed and styled for a different look, to get me thru the next few months at work). my 16 yr old has never seen me without my wig or a scarf or hat - i've been too afraid to traumatize him, except i'm realizing now that he's been traumatized by the whole cancer thing anyway, seeing mom bald isn't going to make anything worse for him, right? - so  i'm going to work up the nerve later today to ask him to take some pictures so i can download them here. have a good hair growing day ... i love that!

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 02:42PM - edited Jul 2, 2009 02:43PM by Lisa810 Cindy, I'm sad to hear your hair is still being so stubborn to come back in. I agree, I know it's hard, but try to let the acupuncture do it's thing. I bet you'll see happier results in a few weeks. Sue, mega-congrats on the FOD & FOW! I couldn't be any happier for or prouder of you! Maggie, maybe if you do make it to the salon (maybe next week?), they'll be able to give you a trim that will help camouflage the thinning you have on top. But I completely hear you on not wanting ANYTHING cut. i think you look supercute as is! I have about another half inch than in my avatar picture. And it's so soft and silky and NOY GREY and not really mousey brown, either. Who woulda thought? (I've been highlighting my hair since I was 25, so I had no clue what my true color was.) I'm nearly to the baseball hat stage. and i've been whipping The Wig off and showing more friends/fam what the real me looks like. Very bummed about my still-receding brows and still-disappearing lashes. I'm 6 weeks out, dammit. So unfair. Very NOT bummed about my implant exchange surgery next weds - whoo hoo! Goodbye 'rocky' and 'ahnold', hello 'Raquel' and 'Sophia'!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 12:03PM - edited Jul 23, 2009 12:03PM by Lisa810 Lainey, can I say how much I love your 'do? You and I seem to have the same regrowth rate, I'm about 8 weeks behind you (gotta change my avatar). I actually made hubby measure my hair the other day. One inch exactly. It's just starting to go past my ears. *happy hairgrowth dance* Chelev, kudos to you for going topless, albeit accidentally, lol! too funny, since for the past week I nearly forgot my wig too! You look adorable! You have a face that's very well suited to short hair. And are those your brows or do you enhance them? gorgeous! i too am going topless in public more and more. (ok, well, just when I walk the dog. And once when I dropped the boy off at band practice.) This weekend will be the first time I'll go sans wig and makeup in front of the inlaws. I'm a bit nervous, I don't know why. They love me to pieces. I'm having great results with Biotin B-Complex Thickening Shampoo from Avalon Organics. Although I guess it could also be the biotin in my multivitamin (tho my legs and underarm hair is coming back reeeeeeeeeaaaaaaaaalllllllyyyyyyy slowly, not that i'm complaining). i shampoo every day, and leave it on my scalp while i wash. My eyelashes are still short and stubby and practically nonexistent. I've been experimenting with Talika & Ardell, but I think I'm going to try sticking with Mavala Eye-Lite Double Lash for a month and see what happens. I'm too nervous to try revitalash. i really really want my hair back, but i also really really want my lashes back too. FYI: seems like my hair's coming in pretty straight (normally it's wavy). And still very little grey. Yay! "I'm thinking these doctors need to read some of these threads." Amen to that, Titan! Magnola, congrats on the soft foobs! I had my exchange july 8th - and even tho I had lipo on the sides, I'm amazed at the fast recovery. (although when I flex, I still fell like the expanders are there. i'm hoping in time it'll feel more natural. tryin' not to worry.)

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 03:41PM Lisa810 wrote: Lisa1964 - i was looking at some photos from last year, and felt the same exact way. i keep telling myself that i didn't know i was "hatching" cancer. i may be fat and bald now, but at least i'm cancer-free. i found the best product ever for eyebrows: Dalton, The Brow Fix Natural Look Brow Gel with Brush from QVC. i was using the anastacia brow kit, but this one is so much better. you just brush the gel on, you don't have to be exact, i'm actually quite sloppy with it, and then when you comb it thru with the brow brush, it looks totally natural. i got the blonde tint, and i'm so loving it, i may keep using it when my brows come back. tip: you can't really use this is you have NO brows. i still have my natural arches, they're just patchy. my hair's about half and inch all around now (my last chemo was 5/13). it's so soft, i love it! i can't tell if i have greys or not. still won't go out without my wig, but at least i'm comfy walking around topless at home now.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2009 02:31PM Lisa810 wrote: Tomorrow I'll be 11 weeks pFc. I was lucky, my hair came in dark. Only now do I see the greys sprouting here and there. Mom_of_boys, this is my natural color. Which I haven't seen since, oh, about 1988, lol! "Before cancer, I had to have every hair in place and would panic if it was messed up." Ditto, Leeayn! I was mega hair-obsessed. Humidity was my number one nemesis. Now? HA! I laugh in the face of fog & drizzle! That's actually the part i loved about wearing the wig. my hair ALWAYS looked good. (((jewlls))) losing my hair was the worst part of this entire BC thing. Somehow, tho, after all my crying and by the time I'd lost most of it in the shower (I didn't buzz), I was ok with it. I even opened the window and sent some of my hair flying out on the breeze, almost ceremoniously. It's amazing what you'll learn to accept. You're stronger than you think. Honest. I promise. Susan13, I am so lovin' your ‘do! your wigs were fab, but you truly rock the short ‘do! Your munchkin is heart-melting adorable! Francine, so sorry to hear about your infection. Hoping you heal soon sooner soonest. Dawn, one week pFc will turn into 4, then 9, then 11 ... it's amazing how time flies once chemo's over. During chemo, time seemed to STOP. For me, anyway. Titan, chelev, Maggie, kjbell, florbo, Judy ... thanks for your kind words and encouragement. This thread helped keep my spirit afloat during my bleakest moments. I only hope I'm paying it forward a bit.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 02:46PM Lisa810 wrote: Susan, so glad you went "topless" and are nearly done with rads! I'm really happy for you, sweetie! Chelev, you poor thing you. Here's hoping your infection clears up fast, now that have a treatment for it. Blake, I'm in love with your hairstyle in your avatar. Is that a wig? Do you have a larger picture you can post? Lainey, if I look half as stunning as you do in a few weeks, I'll go topless too! i've just read back about 10 pgs in here and have a list a mile long of products i want to go out and buy. i've been using the nioxin scalp therapy 2 since before my hair fell out. my stylist said it would help keep my scalp/follicles in top condition, and it just feels so good (i leave it on as a mask while i shower). now that i've got fuzz (only one week out of chemo, yay!), i'm going to keep using it. i also just started taking a multivitamin with biotin (altho my oncologist is very against supplements). for my brows & eyelashes, i'm using Ardell Brow & Lash Accelerator Treatment Gel. have no clue if it's working, but i like feeling proactive. i think i'm gonna try mane & tail and the biotin shampoo next. and definately the logona herbal hair color when i get the medical green light ... tho i am curious to see how gray i am. i've been coloring for 25 yrs, so i have no idea! i won't be ditching The Dreaded Wig anytime soon, tho. i too have a high profile job. and truth be told, i'm more comfortable looking as much as me as possible.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 01:18PM Lisa810 wrote: hello, ladies. wondering if someone can direct me to the proper thread about what to expect from chemo. i had my surgery first, and now chemo & radiation and hormone therapy will be preventative. i have yet to meet my oncologist, so i won't know my regimen until 1/28. all i know right now is that i'll be on Tamoxifen for 6-12 weeks. i read the shopping list for chemo thread last night, and was up half the night crying. i am better if i'm prepared, but i just wasn't expecting all the possibilites of what can go wrong. i think i read too much at once. i'm miserable about losing my hair & eyebrows, i can't bear the thought of going to a wig salon, but cannot imagine how one can possible buy a decent wig online. i don't even know where to begin as to researching supplements. i'll be working thru my chemo ... and whereas my coworkers are kind and supportive and love me, all i can picture is not making it to the ladies room in time to puke. i'm just so depressed and confused. sorry for crashing this thread, but any guidance to the proper threads would be greatly appreciated. i don't suppose there's a "happy chemo stories" thread? *weak smile*

I'm on day 10 of my hair loss (day 25 after 1st AC), started wearing the wig last tuesday (do you EVER get used to it?!), and rotating the 2 beanies & 2 scarves at home. i can't imagine going out in public with just a scarf. not yet anyway. on a quest for "hipper" styles than what you usually find. I stumbled upon this one last night: http://www.hats-for-cancer-patients.com/chemo-hats-novelty-prints.html and then this one this morning: http://www.softhats.com/cancer-hat.php?sku=S011 just thought I'd share. You are such a carebear ... and completely more adorable than mia! thanks to (((everyone))) for the regrowth pics!  It's heartening to hear there's a possibility of regrowth during taxol, since i finish AC on march 18th - if all goes well - and start taxotere april 1st. *heavy sigh*

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2008 11:29PM - edited Dec 4, 2008 11:36PM by Lisa810 ruby, thanks so much for your response. i'm sorry you're going thru this too. please let me know your surgery date so i can keep you in my prayers as well.  i don't have enough tissue to do a tram flap for both breasts. so if i do the bilateral, then it's chest expanders until chemo's over, then implants. stupidly, i thought they could do the implants the same day as the bilateral. funny, all my life i've been overly self-conscious about being so busty. and now i'm going to feel self-conscious being relatively "flat" until september or so. go figure. sue, thank you also for your input, i so appreciate it, and may take you up on your kind offer. your sitch is so very similar to mine. and yes, my biggest fear (outside of losing my hair and eyebrows, and, um, dying) is going thru mastectomy & recon surgery, recovery, the horrors of chemo and then having to go thru it all over again, perhaps immediately. i'd jump off a bridge. hugs to you (((both))) for helping me out tonite.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 10:54PM - edited Feb 13, 2009 11:01PM by Lisa810 BerkeleyKim, i hope your insurance woes right themselves. you so don't need that crap right now! ddlatt, that is all just so wrong! kudos to you for speaking up - i hope they figure out a better way. diane, i'm with you on the sore hysteria. i have what feels like two tiny sores (i think) on my tongue, and my throat feels icky. luckily i can tolerate the biotene now and i'm drinking lemon throat coat. i'm trying not to panic. kathy, many thanks for the constipation tips. i again had another trying bout with my natural senna (altho a good cleaning out is, um, all good - sorry TMI!) ... i can't seem to find the right rhythm and i want to be better prepared for this week's tx. does the Miralax powder taste icky? my onc recommended it also, but i can't abide the taste of chalky stuff, not even tums or pepto or mylanta, even on a good day, much directly after treatment. soothing hugs for (((everyone))). and a special sending-you-all-good-thoughts hug for (((07Rescue))).
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Lisa810 wrote: Hello all. Please forgive me, as I'm a newbie and haven't figured out how to navigate this wonderful forum yet. I'm sure my questions have been answered elsewhere, but I just don't have it in me to search. I'm 48, a 36DDD, recently been diagnosed with IDC left breast, at least 4 lymph nodes affected. ER positive. Met with my breast cancer surgeon on Tuesday, and we both ruled out a partial mastectomy, based on the size and shape of the tumor. I will definately at least have a mastectomy. When I brought up bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction, she said she would fully support that decision. (My mom was diagnosed with breast cancer at 58 and then battled colon cancer several years later; she's 72 and very healthy these days.) Today I met with the plastic surgeon, who I instinctively like and trust. He said I'm an excellent candidate for a tram flap if I opt for the single mastectomy. But he was vague when I asked how I'd "balance" life with a DDD on one side and a "growing bump" on the other until after my chemo is done - which is when he'd do my right side breast reduction. Meanwhile, the MRI report mentions "stippled foci" in my right breast, which I understand is "nothing" but in reality, could be something brewing and will bear close observation. My breast cancer surgeon said I'd be having MRI's every 6 months for the rest of my life, implying they'd find anything else early on but still ... I have huge, dense, always-lumpy-feeling breasts. I didn't even find the lump in my left breast until my breast started dimpling and changing shape. My GP said, if it was her, she'd go for the bilateral, for peace of mind and aesthetics (ie: matching). The plastic surgeon said if it was his wife or mother or daughter, he'd recommend bilateral also. The breast cancer surgeon didn't commit, but I plan on asking her the same question. But ultimately, no matter how many opinions I gather, this is on me and me only. And even a bilateral doesn't guarantee 100% that any small tiny cells of remaining breast tissue won't develop breast cancer. If I only have the one breast removed,  a prosthesis to match my remaining DDD is not an option. The thing would weigh a ton. If I have both removed, going flat chested is also not for me. I still want at least a semblance of my hour-glass figure. I've never liked lugging these boobs around. I've always wanted breast reduction surgery, but was too chicken and afraid of scarring. (Heh.) But now that I know what it's going to take and how long it'll be to look & feel "normal" again ... ugh. My brain is reeling. I'm so confused, I almost feel like going eeny meeny miney mo to make this decision.  I've been really strong & brave these past three weeks. Today I feel like I could crumble to the ground and never get up again. Gah.  Thanks for listening. I hope I can be of help to some of you when I get my brain back on straight.  "just keep swimming, just keep swimming ..." Dx 11/20/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, 2/15 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Tram flap vs bilateral mastectomy Lisa810 browneyes2323

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 10:47AM Lisa810 wrote: i just found out my regimen yesterday. starting 2/4 - 8 am, 4xAC, 4xT, neulesta shot the day after. i won't be finished until the end of may. *pout* they really didn't give me any special instructions for weds, except to eat a normal breakfast & i probably won't be up to driving. i had no idea the sessions last 4 hours! i'm bringing a book & magazines & my ipod. what about stuff to drink? i'm afraid of having to pee every 5 minutes. (i'm the queen of Nervous Bladder Syndrome.) monday = wig salon & port surgery.  i'm a little stunned this is happening so quickly. (((group hug)))

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 03:10PM Lisa810 wrote: i've gained nearly 15 lbs since starting AC dd treatments on 2/4, and it's making me miserable. and i have no good excuse, since my SE's have been very mild, even the fatigue. i haven't even been walking the dog. my onc actually counciled me to go back on weight watchers. he said he's seen people gain 45 lbs on chemo. i can see how easily that can happen. i've been all about the comfort food, even junk food. i'm really out of control. i need to get a grip on this before i start the  steroid overdose for taxotere this week. i love the "5 minutes" advice above - thanks, LibraGirl! - i'm going to try that. hey, maybe we can turn this into a "kick my butt, please" thread ... unless one exists already? we can motivate one another to keep moving.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 08:35PM Lisa810 wrote: patti, it gives me hope that you're embracing The Bald. i feel so much better now that i found a wonderful, warm & knowledgable wig specialist - and the perfect wig (and two cute beanies & two lovely scarves). i feel ready now. i bet you can pull off The Bald. i'm hoping for the natalie portman look in "v for vendetta" ... but i don't have her graceful swan neck. alas. lol @ renrel's "the worlds most painless braxilian sans wax" ... hee! i'm there too right alongside you, shockedat39, with the depression. cried myself sick last saturday. more than i have since this whole shitty thing started. but then i had a great sunday with my visiting-from-VA sister and 19-mo goddaughter (wee ones = my favorite antidepressants!)  ... lucked out with my wig angel on monday ... got the port installed monday night relatively unscathed ... realized that this is it, it's "real" now ... and here i am, done with my first AC treatment. so far so good. (eeep. hope i haven't jinxed it!) anyone have any protein suggestions? i'm not a huge fan of chicken. i can do eggs, peanut butter, cheese, yogurt, nuts, but i'm also trying to go a little bland to start - don't want to get blocked up. does anyone have any favorite protein shakes - storebought or homemade? and also hard candies ... i'm not a hard candy person, but i think it'll help with the icky taste. (not that it's that bad yet.) i bought some crystallized ginger, but i'm saving those for possible nausea attacks on-the-go. soothing hugs & feel good vibes for (((everyone))).
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 07:42PM Lisa810 wrote: *delurks* hello, ladies. my name is Lisa and i had a bilateral mastectomy on 12/30 with reconstruction. luckily i'm cancer-free, but my surgeon said i need chemo/radiation as a preventative. i meet my oncologist for the first time on wednesday. i'm so afraid of chemo, i've had a hard time even just lurking in this thread, even tho i know it's the best way to lessen my fear. everytime i read about the side effects, i have gut feelings i'm going to suffer them ALL and i start crying. funny, i figured once i got thru the surgery, i'd be superstrong for the chemo, but it's turning out to be quite the opposite. i've never been more terrified. i've never felt more weak. i'm trying my best to be proactive. i went to the optomotrist and ordered sassy new glasses, in case i can't wear my contacts due to dry eye. i plan on wig shopping on monday with my sister. i can't see myself shaving when the time comes. i get nauseous just thinking about losing my hair. Diane/shockedat39, thank you for sharing how much you love your wig: "I LOVE my wig ... If you saw any of my posts before I actually had it done, you will know that I was one of the most horrified ladies about losing my hair."  you've given me a teeny bit of hope. *weak smile* can I ask where you wig-wearers bought your wigs? did you go to a salon or order one online?  tons of feel-good vibes to you all. you're all Super Heroes to me. i'm in awe. *relurks*
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 08:22PM Lisa810 wrote: thanks to (((everyone))) for your protein & candy suggestions ... i am dutifully adding them to this weekend's shopping list. luckily i stumbled across some really good root beer candies today. and i forgot how much i love butterscotch ... they will certainly tide me over. thank you plutz & lisalisa ! i think i may be "off" fish for a while ... i'm bummed because it's the mr's birthday and we want to take him to our favorite seafood restaurant this weekend (their fresh, wild salmon is to die for!)... and i may have to make due with steak. but just the thought of tunafish or tilapia or salmon right now ... um, no. (((BerkeleyKim))) hope today was a better day for you, hon. pamela, i agree, you wear your age - and your wig - very well!
